exercises.title: Perfective Stem Formation
exercises.instructions: Fill in the blank with the correct Aorist form. Use the perfective stem with appropriate preverb.

questions.question: Present: მე ვწერ [me vts'er] - 'I write' → Aorist: მე _____ [me _____] - 'I wrote'
questions.explanation: The verb 'to write' forms its perfective stem by adding the preverb და- [da-]. So ვწერ becomes დავწერე in Aorist.

questions.question: Present: მე ვკითხულობ [me vkit'khulob] - 'I read' → Aorist: მე _____ [me _____] - 'I read'
questions.explanation: The verb 'to read' uses the preverb წა- [ts'a-] for perfective aspect. The Aorist form is წავიკითხე or წაიკითხე.

questions.question: Present: მე ვხედავ [me vkhedav] - 'I see' → Aorist: მე _____ [me _____] - 'I saw'
questions.explanation: The verb 'to see' has a suppletive perfective stem. The imperfective is ვხედავ, but the perfective is ვნახე (different root).

exercises.title: Identifying Preverbs
exercises.instructions: Identify which preverb is used in each Aorist form.

questions.question: What preverb is used in 'დავწერე' [davts'ere] - 'I wrote'?
questions.explanation: The preverb და- [da-] is used in დავწერე. This preverb adds perfective aspect and often means 'completion'.

questions.question: What preverb is used in 'წაიკითხა' [ts'aikit'kha] - 'he read'?
questions.explanation: The preverb წა- [ts'a-] is used in წაიკითხა. This preverb adds perfective aspect and can have directional meaning 'away'.

exercises.title: Complete Aorist Sentences
exercises.instructions: Transform the present tense sentence to Aorist, including the correct case shift.

questions.question: Present: მე ვწერ წერილს [me vts'er ts'erils] → Aorist: მე _____ _____ [me _____ _____]
questions.questionGeorgian: აწმყო: მე ვწერ წერილს → აორისტი: მე _____ _____
questions.explanation: Verb changes to perfective stem: ვწერ → დავწერე. Object shifts from Dative წერილს to Absolutive/Nominative წერილი.

questions.question: Present: ბავშვი კითხულობს წიგნს [bavshvi kit'khulobs ts'igns] → Aorist: _____ _____ _____ [_____ _____ _____]
questions.explanation: Subject becomes Ergative: ბავშვი → ბავშვმა. Verb: კითხულობს → წაიკითხა. Object: წიგნს → წიგნი (Dative to Absolutive).

exercises.title: Understanding Polypersonal Agreement
exercises.instructions: Answer questions about polypersonal agreement markers in Series II.

questions.question: In 'მან დამიწერა წერილი' [man damits'era ts'erili] - 'He wrote me a letter', what does the marker 'მ-' in 'დამიწერა' indicate?
questions.explanation: The marker მ- [m-] in Series II indicates first person object ('me'). The subject is third person (მან 'he'), and the object marker shows who received the letter.

questions.question: What is the difference between 'დავწერე' [davts'ere] and 'დაწერე' [dats'ere] in Aorist?

options.text: დავწერე is first person, დაწერე is second person
დავწერე is past tense, დაწერე is present tense

questions.explanation: დავწერე [davts'ere] has the first person marker ვ- [v-] (I wrote). დაწერე [dats'ere] is second person singular (you wrote) without a subject marker.

exercises.title: Intransitive vs Transitive in Aorist
exercises.instructions: Identify whether the verb is transitive or intransitive and how it affects case marking.

questions.question: In the sentence 'მე ვირბინე' [me virbine] - 'I ran', why is the subject 'მე' NOT in Ergative case?

options.text: Because it's present tense, not past
Because 'to run' is an intransitive verb, so no case shift occurs
Because first person never takes Ergative

questions.explanation: Intransitive verbs (like 'to run') don't trigger the case shift. Their subjects remain in Nominative case in all series, including Aorist. Only transitive verbs show the Ergative-Absolutive alignment in Series II.
